keywords.value: Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)
keywords.name: subject

docs.lead_paragraph:
The Affordable Care Act has prompted one of the
largest expansions of mental health coverage in a
generation, increasing access for millions, but shortfalls persist.

headline.main: Expansion of Mental Health Care Hits Obstacles
headline.print_headline: Expansion of Mental Health Care Hits Obstacles

docs.abstract: Affordable Care Act has vastly expanded mental health coverage, defining it as an essential benefit to be covered by Medicaid and every private plan sold through online insurance markets, but shortfalls persist; many private therapists are refusing to take Medicaid or are reporting that many patients coming to them through Medicaid coverage are too challenging to treat (Series: Remaking Medicine).
docs.snippet:
The Affordable Care Act has prompted one of the
largest expansions of mental health coverage in a
generation, increasing access for millions, but shortfalls persist.

keywords.value: Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)
keywords.name: subject

docs.lead_paragraph: Why are women doing most of the work on so many urban farms?
docs.abstract: Work on New York's nearly 900 food gardens and urban farms is primarily done by women, raising questions of whether it is stereotypes or willingness to nurture communities that are reason for such uneven staffing; advocates of urban farming wonder how gender disparity will affect movement's farming model, mission and pay structures.
docs.snippet: Why are women doing most of the work on so many urban farms?

docs.lead_paragraph: Estimates of future medical spending keep falling. The changes are projected to save taxpayers hundreds of billions of dollars.

headline.main: Medicare: Not Such a Budget-Buster Anymore
headline.print_headline: Medicare: Not Such a Budget-Buster Anymore

docs.abstract: The Upshot; Congressional Budget Office continues to reduce its estimate for Medicare spending in coming years; six years of consistent reductions mean federal government's long-term budget deficit is considerably less severe than commonly thought, and that health care may be starting to stabilize as a share of national spending.
docs.snippet: Estimates of future medical spending keep falling. The changes are projected to save taxpayers hundreds of billions of dollars.

byline.original: By MARGOT SANGER-KATZ and KEVIN QUEALY

docs.lead_paragraph: With foreign investment falling, inland provinces are in a cutthroat competition to attract local industries.

headline.main: Gift-Bearing Officials Try to Lure Chinese Factories Inland
headline.print_headline: Gift-Bearing Officials Try to Lure Chinese Factories Inland

docs.abstract: Officials from inland Chinese provinces are offering businesses significant financial incentives to move from China's coastal areas; incentives include deeply discounted land, less-intrusive environmental inspections and lower wages; with foreign investment falling, companies that are trying to cut costs are increasingly taking the offers seriously.
docs.snippet: With foreign investment falling, inland provinces are in a cutthroat competition to attract local industries.
